About Us

Helping the government and education Sectors become meet WCAG Status.

Kaffeinated Kodemonkey is an Accessibility Agency

Our A11y Developers are DHS Certified Trusted Testers and use the trusted tester process. Paired with an A11y platform, your team can add WCAG compliance to their workflow with ease.

Our A11y team follows POUR web design, for an A11y-First approach in design and compliance status.

  • Perceivable - Users must be able to perceive the information being presented
  • Operable - Users must be able to operate the interface
  • Understandable - Users must be able to understand information & operations
  • Robust - Users must be able to access the content as technology advances

This approach can improve ROI through on-site SEO and help ward off potential lawsuits involving accessibility compliance.

Get an accessibility audit Today and understand your compliance status.

"Helping the government and education Sectors meet WCAG requirements through an A11y-First approach to determine ADA compliant status."

With a background in front-end development and working in the education and government, our team saw a rise in demand for web accessibility and decided to take a look. Once we understood the importance of ADA compliance, our team dove in, and made the shift to a web accessibility agency.

What is ADA compliance, WCAG, Section 508...

Kaffeinated Kodemonkey is now offering accesibility seivices with an A11y-First approach to web design, digital content, POC Certifications, ADA compliance, and compliance Status. Our A11y Developers are DHS Certified Trusted Testers and use the Trusted Tester process.

Learn More

Complete A11y for your business

Kaffeinated Kodemonkey is your SME in ADA compliance. Our team ensures your digital content is equally accessible to everyone. The government and education sectors are most at risk for lawsuits if they ignore web accessibiltiy implementation. Also if companies in the privect sector release inaccessible digital content, they are leaving the company vulnerable to lawsuits that will cost the company more money in the long run.


What Accessibility Service is right for you? Talk to a A11y Developer Today!

Frequently Asked Questions

  • Can web accessibility improve SEO?

    If you are on a budget and need to choose between marketing or accessibility, take accessibility every time.

    By implemting an A11y-First approch to design, the user experience will be perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust; and increase your site’s organic visibility.

    Heres the thing, Web Accessibility and SEO go hand in hand. Having great accessibility practices will naturally lead to great SEO practices. Why, you ask? This is because if you follow the W3C POUR Principles you will set yourself up for success in both areas.

    Websites designed with an A11y-First approch, natural generates on-site SEO. Accessibility adds additional information about the site and pages that helps search engines display search results that more accurately match the query request.

  • Why you should add accessibility now and not later?

    If your product is not accessible when you release it, you risk a lawsuit. The judge does not care if you "plan" to make it accessible later. The judge may give you some leeway, but that "plan" just became right now. Pluse you may be hit with a fee and or fines if not done by x date. However this is on the extream level.

    For most of us, this goes back to the topic I coverd above, "Can web accessibility improve my search engine optimization?". With yes being the overall answer, I would ventuer to say you are loosing potential traffice to your site causing in potential lost of revinew because the page never showed up in search results.

    With all that said, say one chooses not to implemnt web accessibiligty durning the design phase.

    Not only are you out the legal fees if taken to court, but also the cost of hiring an agency or developer to remedy accessibility issues. If you have an in-house dev team, you may be able to save some cost, yet you are still out of legal fees. If you do not have an in-house dev team, you are out the cost of legal fees plus the additional cost of a developer to work with the accessibility developer. To take it one step further lets say the site or application was developed years ago, this may entitle a complet redevelopemt; this may be costly and may lead to a new design. If this applys to you, I would advise talking to an A11y developer and getting an plane in place now be for it becomes too costly.

    In either case, hiring the right team from the beginning and including accessibility in the product will save time, money, and hassle.

  • What is ada Complince?

    The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) is a federal civil rights law that prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities in everyday activities. The ADA prohibits discrimination on the basis of disability just as other civil rights laws prohibit discrimination on the basis of race, color, sex, national origin, age, and religion. The ADA guarantees that people with disabilities have the same opportunities as everyone else to enjoy employment opportunities, purchase goods and services, and participate in state and local government programs.

    Introduction to the Americans with Disabilities Act

    There are at least three reasons that might motivate a company to create accessible web content:

    1) To improve the lives of people with disabilities (human-centered motivations)
    2) To capitalize on a wider audience or consumer base (marketing or economic-centered motivations)
    3) To avoid lawsuits and/or bad press (public relations and punishment-centered motivations)


    A11y-driven websites accomplish these goals when people are at the center of the process.

    The Kaffeinated Kodemonkey team strives to use the POUR principles set forth by the WCAG:

    Perceivable - Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive. This means that users must be able to perceive the information being presented (it can't be invisible to all of their senses)

    Operable - User interface components and navigation must be operable. This means that users must be able to operate the interface (the interface cannot require interaction that a user cannot perform)

    Understandable - Information and the operation of the user interface must be understandable. This means that users must be able to understand the information as well as the operation of the user interface (the content or operation cannot be beyond their understanding)

    Robust - Content must be robust enough that it can be interpreted reliably by a wide variety of user agents, including assistive technologies. This means that users must be able to access the content as technologies advance (as technologies and user agents evolve, the content should remain accessible). Those who are simply trying to avoid lawsuits realize must consider and address people with disabilities within their targeted audience.

  • Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

    A set of standards that requires federal government to make ICT (information and communications technology) accessible to employees and members of the public with disabilities; the same experience as employees and members of the public without disabilities.

    In 1998, congress amended the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, requiring federal government to make electronic and digital content accessible to people with disabilities.

    In 2018 Section 508 was update to reflect the WCAG requirments and international standards. This rulling applies to all government agencies when it pertains to digital content and electronic documents. Government agencies must give disabled employees and members of the public access to the same or comparable information as they do others.

    The U.S. Access Board is responsible for developing compliance standards that govern Federal procurement practices. January 2017, they issued a final rule that updated requirements for section 508 and refreshed guidelines to Section 255 in response to market trends and innovations in technology. The refresh also harmonized these requirements with other guidelines and standards both in the U.S. and abroad, including standards issued by the European Commission, and W3C guidelines know as WCAG.

  • ADA and Public-Private Website

    Accessibility standards issued under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) apply to places of public accommodation, commercial facilities, federal, state, and local government facilities in new construction, alterations, and additions. The ADA Standards are based on minimum guidelines set by the Access Board.

    The Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Department of Transportation (DOT) issue the ADA Standards. DOJ’s ADA Standards apply to all facilities except public transportation facilities, which are subject to DOT’s ADA Standards. This version of the ADA Standards combines both documents and notes unique provisions in the DOJ Standards and the DOT Standards. The Access Board is responsible for providing technical assistance and training on these Standards.

    Title II applies to State and local government entities. Title III of the ADA ensures that places of public accommodations and commercial facilities, such as restaurants, movie theaters, and doctors’ offices, are accessible. Although web accessibility does not explicitly state, if a business offers products and services on their website or mobile apps, they must ensure that people with disabilities have equal access; I would play it safe.
